@HandNF I take your point about pandering. My question (which is probably better aimed at people who study such things) is how much a person's accent just changes as they become immersed in a new dialect environment. & what drives the variation.

@HandNF I think the extent to which people's accents change in adulthood varies. My grandparents all had strong accents, & 2/3 of them arrived in this country young (though Pop had no English when he got here.) My mother's accent became more & more American. But she married a Yank.

Welly golly-gee, this sound a bit hyperbolic. A bit end-of-the-worldian, maybe? Come on, Woodward, that's not your lane (as @NRA would say). Say in your lane. This is the kind of talk best left to histrionic tweeters. Like @jsundmanus. https://t.co/5YBf2ueTv6

@joy P.S. I'm one of those people who get all prissy about not calling New Jersey "Jersey" (except when referring to the Jersey Shore, which is acceptable & proper). Yes, I know, this is an affectation like wearing a bow tie & spats. But it's who I am.

@joy John F. Kennedy & RFK & Ted Kennedy did not speak with a "Massachusetts accent" or a "Boston accent." They spoke with a Kennedy accent -- especially JFK. I've lived in Massachusetts since 1980 & my 3 children were born in Boston. Where nobody speaks with a Kennedy accent. fin/

@joy (1) I don't know anything about North Jersey, although I do have a secret hope to someday visit Jersey. My only remotely-related experience is with northern New Jersey. (2) My question remains, why doesn't Bernie sound more like his constituents? Please note. . .(cont'd)

@joy But it's the vocal patterns that I'm talking about! BTW, I grew up on a small farm in North Caldwell, New Jersey. Cows, sheep, chickens, etc. The kids I played with had parents from Italy, Greece & Lebanon. North Caldwell is now known worldwide as Tony Soprano's home town.
RT @yoricknixon: @jsundmanus Interesting tho I'm not sure I'm grokking the point. E.g., Henry Kissinger's brother (who had almost no discer…
@yoricknixon I'm not asserting the same thing about Bernie (that he has a narcissistic inability to listen), but I am raising that question.

@joy Valid points. But does Bernie sound anything like the typical Burlintonite, or like his typical constituent? My main question is about whether he listens to or sounds like the people he represents.

(Ooops! please edit 6 --> 7 in preceding tweet.) Anyway, as somebody who grew up amid immigrants with nuanced accents, and as a would-be polyglot myself, accents interest me. And I think Bernie Sanders's enduring accent is because Bernie is all about Bernie Sanders. end/

Also note that I put "Brooklyn accent" in quotes, because (a) there are, or at least used to be, several distinct sub-variants of Brooklyn accents, and (b) I have several friends age 60+, born & raise in Brooklyn who speak pretty much bland national-average Americanese. 6/
[For what it may matter, I voted for Sanders in the 2016 Massachusetts primary.]

Sanders has been in Vermont for fifty years. Why doesn't he in any way sound like the people he represents? My guess? Because he doesn't listen, and he doesn't have any real self-identification as a Vermonter. 6/
Those actors mastered American/Brooklyn accents because it mattered to them. And of course, because they have amazing talent & worked hard at it. But the motivation comes first. 5/

But consider the movie "The Drop", James Gandolfini's (Tony Soprano) last movie. https://t.co/mcQe7294gL Three of the four actors portraying Brooklynites are not American. 2 of them don't even have English as a first language. 4/

Also I have lived overseas & learned a few languages & have been informed about my American accent when speaking French, Wolof, Pulaar, Vietnamese, etc. I worked hard to learn these languages, but still had an accent. 3/

My mother & all of my maternal relatives were immigrants from Scotland. My paternal grandparents, who lived in the same house with me until I was 18, were immigrants from Finland and Ireland. Most of my relatives were immigrants or 1st generation 2/
Bernie Sanders has lived in Vermont since 1968 & still has an exaggerated "Brooklyn" accent. I think this says something important about him. 1/

Amen. Clinton is not without faults. No politician at her level is or even comes close except maybe Lincoln (but let's not go there right now). HRC went with Bush on Iraq & then fucked up Libya. Bad. But she's still on a par with Obama, the best on offer for decades. And she won. https://t.co/mtASgAEjqT
